Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogeny, biogeography, and population genetics of Scirpus (Cyperaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
An understanding of the evolutionary and ecological processes that have contributed to the diversity and distribution of our flora is critical for effective conservation strategies in this era of rapid climate change. Utilizing state-of-the-art DNA sequencing technologies, this research investigates the evolution of the bulrushes, an ecologically important group of wetland species in the sedge family (Cyperaceae), and utilizes this historical context to predict how species with disparate ranges may differentially respond to climate change. Within this evolutionary framework, this study identifies two endangered, narrowly distributed bulrushes and compares them to their most closely related widespread relatives, quantifying the genetic diversity present within their populations and modeling their responses to predicted climatic regimes.

Climate change has been a threat for decades, yet effective mitigation strategies are still nascent. As resources allocated to conservation are limited, it is essential to prioritize by protecting those species most at risk. Using the evolutionary context afforded by this study, this research utilizes the bulrushes as a case study in order to determine if species with narrow ranges are inherently more at risk of extinction under future climates than widespread species. The results of this study will determine whether the range of a species is a useful proxy for extinction risk, thereby allowing for the identification of at-risk species before they become rare and ultimately informing a predictive and preventative, rather than reactive, approach to conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research analyzed the diversification of the sedge family, Cyperaceae - the tenth largest family of vascular plants - at four spatial, temporal, and taxonomic scales. First, we clarified the timing, place, and rate of evolution of the family. We created the most densely sampled chronogram (time-calibrated family tree) of Cyperaceae presented to date, and subjected this chronogram to biogeographical and diversification rate analysis to determine when, where, how quickly the family evolved. We identified a Cretaceous, South American origin for the family and determined long-distance dispersal to be the primary mode by which it has come to occupy its current distribution. We uncovered three increases in diversification rate associated with intercontinental dispersals. We have also demonstrated that genera that consist of narrowly distributed species with non-overlapping ranges are far more likely to be diverse than genera that consist of widespread species with overlapping ranges. This result suggests a key process that explains the area-richness correlation that has been observed in vascular plant families for many years.

Second, we determined the roles of geographical and ecological change in the diversification of the North American Cyperaceae flora. We compiled a phylogeny (family tree) of the North American sedges, for which we also quantified species distributions and characterized their climatic and soil preferences. Our analyses show that evolutionarily related species tend to be geographically unrelated and that rates of geographical and ecological diversification are closely linked to tempo of speciation. In this research, we have developed new methods to integrate geographic data with phylogenetic information in a statistically rigorous fashion.

Third, we constructed a phylogeny of two sedge genera, Scirpus and Eriophorum, with unprecedented resolution. We reconstructed the ancestral biogeography of Scirpus and Eriophorum, demonstrating that the relictual eastern North America – eastern Asia disjunct pattern characterizing Scirpus is the result of “out of America” and “out of Asia” migrations across intercontinental land bridges. We highlighted the evolutionary shifts and adaptations in Eriophorum potentially associated with its shift to arctic climates and circumboreal distribution. 

Fourth, we characterized the structure of genetic diversity of the globally imperiled species, Scirpus longii. We assessed rates of hybridization and invasive introgression with a weedy relative, and reconstructed the phylogeographic and demographic history of the species. Our results indicate that extant populations originated from a single refugium and experienced two genetic bottlenecks in conjunction with Holocene climate fluctuation. The remaining genetic diversity of Scirpus longii exhibits little structure. Future climate scenarios indicate that nearly half of extant populations will occur outside of suitable areas by 2070. These results are being communicated to conservation groups and are being used to develop proactive and targeted conservation strategies.

This project has trained one graduate student in fieldwork, laboratory research, data analysis, and bioinformatics. This project has also trained four undergraduate students, three of which belong to communities that are under-represented in the sciences, in labwork, data management, and data analysis.
